article.title: Single-cell RNA sequencing of the carotid artery and femoral artery of rats exposed to hindlimb unloading
funding: National Natural Science Foundation of China (No. 12132012 and No. 32100952)
article.abstract: Prolonged spaceflight is known to cause vascular deconditioning and remodeling. Tail suspension, a widely used spaceflight analog, is reported to result in vascular remodeling of rats. However, little is known about the cellular atlas of the heterogeneous cells of CA and FA from hindlimb-unloaded rats.

sections.introduction: With the increasing frequency of long-duration spaceflights, astronauts are confronted with a myriad of harsh conditions, including radiation, microgravity and circadian rhythm disruptions. These factors precipitate a cascade of cardiovascular changes, initially characterized by fluid shifts from the lower limbs to the head.
sections.methods: A total of 12 male Sprague-Dawley rats (Fourth Military Medical University, Xi'an, China), aged eight weeks and sourced, were randomly allocated to either the hindlimb unloading (HU, n = 6) or the control group (Con, n = 6).
sections.results: Although scRNA-seq has extensively profiled vascular changes in cardiovascular and metabolic diseases, a detailed single-cell analysis of arterial adaptations in hindlimb-suspended rats remains absent.
sections.discussion: Weightless environment has a wide range of physiological effects on blood vessels. Here, we present a comprehensive CA and FA cell atlas in rats subjected to hindlimb suspension by utilizing scRNA-seq.

article.insights_summary: This study presents the first cellular atlas of the conductive arteries in hindlimb-unloaded rats, revealing a spectrum of cell types and sub-clusters within the carotid and femoral arteries.
